repnme.cdata!:
Brazil, Philippines - Building institutions
            and financing local development : lessons from Brazil and
            the Philippines - Municipal Development Projects in the
            State of Parana and the State of Rio Grande do Sul, First
            and Second Municipal Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This study assesses the impacts of
            municipal development projects (MDPs) on the institutional
            capacity building of local governments for fiscal and
            financial management and for planning and implementation of
            investment programs. It also assesses direct impacts on the
            beneficiaries as anticipated by the projects, and indirect
            side-effects on the development of local economies focusing
            on employment and income generation. The study evaluates the
            impacts of two successful MDPs, in the Philippines and in
            Brazil. They provide a rich base for the study to extract
            lessons for ongoing and future projects. Three sets of data
            were collected and analyzed: municipal finance data of local
            governments, a sample survey of mayors on capacity building,
            and a survey of stall-holders in public markets. At both the
            municipal and the beneficiary levels, the study compared
            impacts on the participating municipalities with conditions
            of the non-participating municipalities, and the initial
            conditions with the impacts after the project implementation.

Brazil, Philippines - Building institutions

            the Philippines - Municipal Development Projects in the
            State of Parana and the State of Rio Grande do Sul, First

442033.projn: BR-Munic Devt (Parana) -- P006435,PH-Municipal Devt II -- P004573,BR-Municip Dev (Rg Sul) -- P006501,PH-Municipal Dev(Second -- P004501

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Municipal Development Project in
            the State of Rio Grande Do Sul

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development Project in the
            State of Rio Grande do Sul, known locally as the PIMES
            project, was the first Bank-supported operation in the State
            of Rio Grande do Sul (RGS) aimed at reforming
            municipalities. The Project used the provision of urban
            infrastructure finance to leverage municipal management
            improvements and introduced a new line of credit with
            quasi-market lending terms and conditions. Its design was
            based upon the Parana Municipal Development Project (Ln.
            3100-BR) appraised four months earlier, but implemented in
            quite different circumstances. Similar follow-on projects
            were later approved for the states of Minas Gerais (Ln.
            3639-BR) and Bahia (Ln.4140-BR). Tlhe project's
            objectives were to: (i) improve the managerial and
            institutional capacity and fiscal efficiency of RGS
            municipalities and state agencies. (ii) Provide basic
            economic and social infrastructure in urban areas. (iii)
            Decentralize urban administration and financial management.
            (iv) Improve targeting of urban programs to lower-income
            populations. (v) Create and strengthen a State urban
            development fund (FUNDOPIMES). In support of these
            objectives, Bank Loan proceeds were on-lent to
            municipalities, their water companies, and the RGS water
            company, CORSAN, to finance their priority investments. In
            addition, intemal management improvements were to be carried
            out. Moreover, the rigorous terms and conditions of
            FUNDOPIMES' lending were themselves an incentive for
            municipalities to reform their finances in order to be able
            to service their project debts comfortably. The kind of
            investments foreseen under the project included street
            paving, drainage, basic sanitation, day care centers and
            health posts. PIMES supported municipal efforts to improve
            their management directly through its institutional
            development (ID) component.

Brazil - Municipal Development Project in

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Municipal Development Project in
            the The State of Rio Grande Do Sul

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development Project in the
            State of Rio Grande Do Sul consists of two components: 1)
            institutional and human resource development and 2)
            infrastructure investments. The first comprises 10 % of the
            total project costs and includes technical assistance,
            training and equipment for : municipalities, the State Water
            Company (CORSAN), and autonomous water companies
            (MWC's) to strengthen their financial management and
            overall administration, and b) BADESUL and other state
            sector agencies, to improve their institutional capacity for
            project management and appraisal of participants and sub
            projects, and c) state and municipal training and technical
            assistance agencies which provide assistance in the areas of
            municipal management and urban development, and
            environmental control. The second component  represents 90 %
            of total project costs and includes water supply and
            sanitation, street paving and lighting, drainage and erosion
            control, solid and toxic waste management, community
            facilities and a pilot project for low income self help
            house construction.

Brazil - Municipal Development Project in
